page.title: 08WESTON
page.content: THE HAMLET OF WESTON LIES ASTRIDE THE RIVER OTTER & IS IN THREE PARISHES- AWLISCOMBE, BUCKERELL & GITTISHAM. THE CENTRE IS MOSTLY COTTAGES WHICH WERE ORIGINALLY THATCHED BUT ARE NOW ROOFED WITH SLATE OR TILE. THE NAME IS PROBABLY A CONTRACTION OF WESSINGTON. THE RIVER WOLF JOINS THE OTTER AT WESTON. REPORT HAS IT THAT IT IS SO NAMED BECAUSE THE LAST WOLF IN ENGLAND WAS KILLED THERE. THERE IS A BRIDGE (CHERRY BRIDGE) & A FORD OVER THE WOLF & TRAFALGAR BRIDGE CARRIES THE ROAD OVER THE OTTER. PRESUMABLY THE LORD OF THE MANOR ONCE LIVED AT WESTON MANOR. WESTON COURT, NEXT DOOR, WAS ONCE THE BARN & STABLES OF THE MANOR. IN THE WALL OF WESTON COURT IS A VICTORIAN LETTERBOX. THERE IS NO CHURCH BUT THERE IS A CHAPEL. THE OTTER INN WITH ITS GARDEN RUNNING DOWN TO THE RIVER IS A FAVOURITE EATING & DRINKING PLACE
